div.p: THE YORKER'S STRATAGEM; OR BANANA'S WEDDING. A FARCE, IN TWO ACTS. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE IN NEW-YORK, BY THE Old American Company of Comedians, WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE.
NEW-YORK: Printed by T. & J. SWORDS, No. 27, William-Street. —1792.—

div.head: TO THE PUBLIC.
div.p: THE Author of the following little Piece is ſenſible of its numerous defects—it was got up in a hurry, and under many diſadvantages. The very flattering marks of approbation, however, with which it was received, together with the preſſing importunities of many friends, have led him to ſuppoſe that a publication of it would not be unpleaſing.

To the generous Patrons of the Drama, and to the worthy Sons of Columbia who feel an intereſt in the welfare of the American Stage, the YORKER'S STRATAGEM is moſt reſpectfully dedicated: and the Author is not without hopes, that this feeble attempt, defective as it is, will meet an apology from every generous heart for its introduction into the world.

div.head: —SCENE I.
div.stage: A Chamber in a Tavern. Amant and Captain Oakum ſeated; Amant dreſſed like a Yankey clown.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: WELL, Captain, here are we arrived in the Weſt-Indies, the climate for life, luxury and faſhion; do you not think I have choſe a pretty fancy dreſs to come aſhore in?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, there are two things which appear very odd to me, and which I own give riſe to ſtrange conjectures.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: In the firſt place, why you ſhould prefer this out-bay, where there are but a few fiſhing-huts and two or three ſtores, to your chance of a market at the principal town; and ſecondly, your coming aſhore in this diſguiſe has ſomething tha appearance of a ſpy.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Well, my dear fellow, to clear your ſuſpicions I will fully acquaint you with my deſign in coming here, and the ſtory that gave riſe to it—It is almoſt needleſs for me to requeſt your ſecrecy and aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: You may depend on me.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: In our converſations about the fair ſex, you have frequently heard me dwell with rapture on the virtues and beauty of a young lady with whom I got acquainted when ſhe was at a boarding-ſchool in York.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I have, Sir, and wiſh'd to aſk you particularly about her, but was afraid it might offend.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Her name is Sophia Bellange, a native of this country; her parents are lately dead. 'Tis a letter from her ſince her arrival here that was the cauſe of my cloſing my affairs at home, and undertaking this journey. She deſcribes her guardian to be avaricious, and totally deſtitute of principle, conſtantly employed in every warrantable theft that the ſimplicity or imprudence of his neighbours will permit him to practiſe.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Well, how do you intend to meet him?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: With his own weapons, artifice and chicane. You muſt introduce me as ſupercargo, a true Yankey, ſent out by daddy with a cargo of lumber, hogs and poultry, to make daddy's own ſon a 'ſquire. My apparent ſimplicity will enſure him a gull, and me an opportunity of ſeeing my miſtreſs, and contriving ſome means to get her and her fortune out of his hands.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: But what part am I to take in this ſcheme?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: You muſt ſay as little as poſſible, appear almoſt as ignorant as myſelf, and depend on me for inſtructions as we go on. Suppoſe we call in the landlord and make ſome enquiry about the old gentleman?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I think it will be neceſſary. But are you Jonathan here?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: In every place 'till I get into the arms of my miſtreſs. (Mimicks) Houſe, houſe, who keeps houſe here? Won't that do?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Oh, very well.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: Did you pleaſe to want any thing?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Don't you think, Captain, that we two might make out with a little apple toddy?

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: That is, Sir, you want a bowl of punch, and a ſlice of pine-apple in it.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: You be drot, do you think I came all the way from Stony-Town, and not know that apples don't grow on pine-trees, and that punch aint toddy?

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir, we have no other apple here except the couſhooe.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Don't tell me about your cow ſhoe, nor your horſe ſhoe, I'll not put up with any of your half laughs, I'll be dur if I do, and that's point blank.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: Sir, I wou'd not wiſh to offend any gentleman.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Then you do think I am a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: I am ſure you look very like one.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Why then, friend, to ſhew you I don't belie my looks I'll be generous, and treat Nathan hear to a bottle of wine; and do you hear, bring a jug of cool water—this country ſeems hot.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Hot enough to ſweat your plank and ſalt fiſh, or I'm miſtaken. Madeira, Sir?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Yes, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Now, an't you a pretty ſort of a landlord and don't know that gentlemen drink French wine?

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Lord! Lord! what an aſs you are.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Why, you play Jonathan better than I expected.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: 'Tis my ſureſt card; ten to one if our landlord is not the firſt to make a report to the old gentleman of the ſimplicity of his gueſts.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: You have chriſten'd me too.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: O yes, remember you are Nathan Goſlin, and I am Jonathan Norrard.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Ay, now, that's ſhip-ſhape, as our mate ſays. Come, landlord, won't you take a glaſs? Come, be bold, I don't value a glaſs of wine a corn-cob, not I. Sit down; it's as cheap ſitting as ſtanding.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: Sir, you are very polite.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Ay, ſo our neighbours' daughters tell me; and now, ſince I've croſs'd the ſeas, I intend to be a great man before I go back to daddy. Pray, friend, do you know one Mr. Fingercaſh, ſome place about here?

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he's my neighbour.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: They talk in our parts that he buys ſuper-cargoes.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: (Aſide.) He'll buy and ſell you if you fall into his clutches. Yes, Sir, he purchaſes cargoes of all ſorts.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Then I think I can ſuit him to a notch—Pray what ſort of a man is he to deal with?

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: As to his honeſty, I would vouch for it as ſoon as for my own—He's my particular friend; if you pleaſe, Sir, I'll introduce you to him; he is vaſtly hoſpitable to ſtrangers: you have never ſeen him, I preſume?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: No, I ſhould not know the man if I was to meet him in my muſh; but I'll be bound he knows daddy.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: What may his name be, Sir?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: What! do'nt you know he? I did'nt think there was a dog in the pariſh but knew Old-Caleb at the ſaw-mill.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: If you pleaſe to favour me with his ſirname—

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: His brother Epram drives more hogs to the market than any five men in our county. The old 'ſquire uſed to ſay that Epram Norrard's word was as good as any man's bond.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: Mr. Norrard, (takes him by the hand) I am very proud, I aſſure you, to ſee you under my roof: how lucky you was in happening to call here: my good friend, make yourſelf at home, be perfectly eaſy about every thing; Mr. Fingercaſh and I will take a pleaſure in getting your cargo off your hands.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I have not the leaſt doubt of that. (Aſide.) But how the plague did you make out to know my name? I'll ſwear you muſt be a witch.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: My dear Sir, I am not unacquainted with the fame and reſpectability of your family. Your own character is now perfectly known to me, and you may reſt ſatisfied I ſhall make it my ſtudy to profit by ſo valuable an acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Not ſo much as you imagine. (Aſide) Then you think I may do in this country?

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, my dear friend; come along with me, and I'll put you in a way of doing for yourſelf in a very little time. Oh you curſed jack-aſs!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Mr. Fingercaſh's houſe. Mr. and Mrs. Fingercaſh.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Well, what's this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: It is ſimply this; we have both agreed not to give our daughter a farthing of portion, till our death, and as the young fellows now a days will not take a girl without a fortune, I think it adviſeable to ſtrike with Mrs. Banana's propoſal of a match between our daughter and her ſon: he has got a fine eſtate, and however defective he may be with regard to education, and that bauble ſentiment, it will be amply made up for by his caſh and canefields.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Well, huſband, do as you will. (Aſide.) I ſhall now get rid of a prying impudent ſtep-daughter.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Maſa Acid dere want for ſee you, he hab two Yankey wid he.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: How do you know they are Yankeys?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Dem tan ſo, dem hab ſalt fiſh in one hand, and trokey in todder.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Something is in the wind; Acid is always on the look-out; quick in ſcent, ſure of his game. Go, go wiſe, break the match to your young pullet, and I'll go and pluck the Yankey geeſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: How I do long to prey upon a bacon-fed Yankey, or porgy-headed Bermudian!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Your ſervant, friend Acid. Gentlemen, your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: This, Sir, is Mr. Norrard, ſupercargo of the brig arrived this morning. His father is as reſpectable—

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Stop, friend, few words are beſt; but if you go to that, daddy won't turn his back on any man in our parts, from a cedar ſhingle to a two-inch plank, and I can prove it down right point blank upon the nail.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: You have brought ſome lumber then?

sp.speaker: Acid.
sp.p: If you get him to anſwer that or any other queſtion in a direct manner, I'll forfeit a dozen of my beſt claret.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, mamy ſent a few corn-fed hogs, and ſiſter Tabithy a few fowls, and ſuch odd notions, to buy ſilken truck like, to make her a gown like.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Any good puncheon ſtaves?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, the 'ſquire of our town did ſhip a few caſks of choice ſalt fiſh, I'm a ſheep's-head if there is better between this and Cape-Cod. Smell that. (Knocks the fiſh againſt his noſe.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: It ſmells well; but that's a rough manner of producing your ſample.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I don't make many compliments, not I; the plain thing is the plain thing, and ſo ſiſter told Nickadamus, when ſhe broke his face laſt huſking time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: (Aſide to Acid.) He'll do, he'll do, he's the thing. Concerning the boards and ſtaves.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Conſidering that the froſt did ſtint the apples, we have got a few barrels nice cyder; it's ſweet as laſſes, an't it Captain?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: There is ro getting a direct anſwer from that thick ſkull of his. (Aſide.) Speaking of apples, have you brought any with you? our ladies are vaſtly fond of them.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, I have brought a plaguey ſight of gingerbread, hickory nutts, and ſuch like truck, to treat the laſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a ſtupid dog! but I'll make his purſe anſwer me if he won't. (Aſide.) Would you be ſo obliging, Sir, as to favour me with a ſight of your invoice, or to make out a ſketch of your cargo?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Aſk Captain, he deals in black and white, and I keep tally.

div.stage: Captain gives him the invoice, and enter Mrs. Fingercaſh, Miſs Bellange, and Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Heavens! the ſight of her has ſo diſconcerted me, I ſhall never be able to go through with it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Where are you going, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: To the plantation, my dear, to break that affair to Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: You muſt defer it, my dear, to receive thoſe ſons of liberty, from the land of freedom, to which they ſhall not return till they have taſted of our hoſpitality. (Aſide.) After I have taxt them firſt pretty high. Smooth them up, my dear, they are flats, down-right flats.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Sons of Columbia, deign to receive the humble welcome of your loweſt ſlave.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I don't underſtand that ſort of talk, not I; Columbus might be a very honeſt ſort of a man, but I would have you to know that I am no baſtard of his, nor any Indian ſon of a—

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: (Clapping his hand on Amant's mouth.) Manners, Jonathan, before the ladies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Wife, you'll ruin all with your figurative ſtuff: divert him with bargaining for his turkeys, while I draw the Captain aſide and found him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: My huſband informs me you have got ſome poultry to diſpoſe of.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: They are all as fat as bacon, I'll be bound for them; feel you the weight of that (offers to give her the turkey; ſhe drops it; he runs after it, and then takes ſome corn out of his pocket and cries) Coobity, coobity, coobity. Oh Lord, what ſhall I do? I muſt never look daddy in the face again, for looſing ſiſter Tabithy's black hen.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Be not afraid, Sir, the Negroes will take care of it.

div.stage: Enter a ſervant, whiſpers Mrs. Fingercaſh.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Miſs Bellange, you are acquainted with the gentleman's country, oblige me by entertaining him till I return. Exit Mrs. Fingercaſh.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Come, Louiſa, this man may perhaps give me ſome information of my Amant; his ſimplicity will afford you a laugh at leaſt. Pray, friend, how does all at home do?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Ay, now Miſs, you ſpeak as if you had been born in a chriſtian country. Our folks are a ſort of ſo, and a ſort of not ſo; ſiſter Jemima has got the mumps, and brother Ebby's heels are all over kibes; all well beſides.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: (Coming forward with the Captain and Acid.) Captain, your ſupercargo ſeems to do better with the young ladies than with my rib. I can tell by his eye he's a rogue amongſt the girls.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I'll be bound, he's a great favourite with our laſſes.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, I have bundled with them, ſparked in Virginia, and played up old Harry all about.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo! By the Lord he's a lad of ſpirit; give me your hand, you dog; who knows but with that plump round face of yours, and that genteel air and carriage, but you may carry off ſome of our Creole girls of fortune? eh, you rogue!

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Who knows but I may? eh, Captain. Pray, Sir, have you got any of them thingumbobs in your ſtore that pleaſe the laſſes?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: My dear fellow, you may ſuit yourſelf there from a ſailor's jacket to the robe of an emperor; the ladies will recommend to you what is moſt faſhionable, and the Captain and I, if he pleaſes, will go and ſee what is to be done over a bottle.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I vow now if that an't right friendly. Go, Captain, and make out bills of invoices, and I'll trade with the ladies for ſome of ſiſter's truck.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what part of America are you from?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Stony-Town laſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Was you ever in York?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Tarnaſhon ſeize the place, I fell downright in love there, and all I ever got for my pains was that there ring. Shews a ring.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Heavens, my Amant! Lend me your hand, Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Curſed impatience, I am diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Be under no apprehenſions, Sir, I am well acquainted with the attachment ſubſiſting between you and Miſs Bellange, and as her friend you have nothing to fear from me.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: My Sophia, (kneeling and kiſſing her hand,) how bleſt am I to preſs this hand unſeen by other eyes than thoſe of friendſhip. Can you forgive, my love, this premature diſcovery, that has ſo ruffled this dear form?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: And can you, Amant, aſk me that queſtion? (Looking tenderly.)

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: No, my angel, I read my welcome in thoſe beauteous eyes, true to the dictates of a heart where love and candour only dwell.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Oh, my Amant! what have I not ſuffered ſince the ſad event that drew me from you!

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: My ſoul felt all your anguiſh; by the ſtrong power of ſympathetic love I ſhared in all your ſorrows, and now am come to ſooth the ſad remembrance, to be your friend, your father, and your —

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: I know the other title you would claim, but am afraid there is an inſurmountable obſtacle in your way to that.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: In ſurmountable, Madam, did you ſay?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Why do you ſtart? you know my heart is only yours, but fortune —

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Well, what of fortune?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Makes it —

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Impoſſible I can be yours.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: And are my flattering hopes thus blaſted? Have I then quit my home in expectation of exalted bliſs, to meet the moſt aggravating of diſappointments?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: You are in an error—do not give way to the impetuoſity of your temper.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Heavens, Madam! is it poſſible I could with patience meet ſuch an unexpected reception?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Sure you do not doubt my ſincerity?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I never did till you began to ſpeak of obſtacles.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: But do you know what they are?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: You are acquainted with them, and that I ſuppoſe is ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Will you but hear me?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: What, to make me more diſtracted than I am?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: This, Sir, is a ſpecimen of your temper I never thought of ſeeing.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: This is a trial I thought it beyond the power of fortune to put it to.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Come, I ſee there is a miſunderſtanding between you, and as it is a relation of mine that is the cauſe of it, I'll endeavour to clear it up.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: A brother, I preſume? Curſed fortune!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: No, Sir, it is my father, without whoſe conſent ſhe cannot give away her hand; and her fortune, (which altho' he ſays is ſmall) has too many charms for him to reſign in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Ah! my Sophia, and is that the only bar that can impede my happineſs?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: The ſole one; and do you not think the want of fortune is a ſtrong one?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: By heaven if there was any circumſtance on earth could make me love you more, it would be to labour againſt difficulties to make you happy; but ſurely my fortune, and abilities in buſineſs, are by no means ſo deſpicable as to take away from my felicity with the woman that could return my love.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: And where is the woman that would not make a return to ſuch a generous heart? Take then my hand, and let your counſel guide my will.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Then I am completely happy; ſecure in your affections, if I even fail in procuring the old gentleman's conſent I ſhall poſſeſs a treaſure which, in my eſtimation, is richer than all theſe Indies can beſtow.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p:
Come, come, pleaſe to lay aſide your love and ſentiment for a period that I hope is not far off, and re-aſſume your character of Jonathan, which you perſonate
ſo well; a thought has ſtruck me, that with the aſſiſtance of a dying ſwain (who I will this moment introduce you to) we may all of us be enabled to ſet ſail for your country, where Virtue gives diſtinction, Induſtry wealth; and where, like Majeſty Divine, the hand that can deal thunder to uſurping foes, diſtributes the bleſſings of Liberty and Concord to his fellow citizens, by the juſtice and wiſdom of his laws.

div.head: —SCENE I.
div.stage: A Chamber in Fingercaſh's Houſe. Enter Frenchman and Mrs. Fingercaſh.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: MADAME, the arrival of this Yankey doodle, or vat you call him, eſt fort apropos, I am tranſporté aux ceiux, ah comme nous ſerons heruex how bliſtered we ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: But will you not deſpiſe me for taking ſo imprudent a ſtep? Conſider he is my huſband.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: C'eſt vrai par de law of de man, but vat is dat to de law of the pitit dieu Cupid in de cour of l'amour? we ſhall be ugé, and I ſa'l be condamné to die vid tranſport on your ſaft a boſom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Oh, you are a flattering creature.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: No, I aſſures you I love you vid a paſſion ſi vive, que je ne puis pas vivre that I can not live vidout you. Ah comme yous etez joli Venus meme eſt moins belle qui vous, vous avaiz tout a fait l'air enjo • e et vos beaux yeux you pritty little eyes, ſo very full of vivacité. Vat you call dat in Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Oh you are an enchanting creature.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Ah, Madame, ſi je puis parle l'Englois comme je parle la François l'ardeur of my language, vould kiſs you very ſoul.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: What animated notions of the paſſion of love you Frenchmen have?

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Madame, l'am dune François eſt faite pour l'amour dem ſoul is made for love, it is dat inſpire dem vid courage to encounter vos charms, and it is dere gloire d'etre vançu to fall you captive.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but after you become our captives you too frequently break your parole d'honneur, and make yourſelves matters of the power by which we ſubdue; as per example, you ſay you are my captive, yet I am ſuch an unguarded general, that I now give myſelf up to your direction, to oppoſe any peril you dare face.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Ah, quelle joi, I am drunk vid my bonheur, I ſall go dans une inſtant and purchaſe the cargaifon of the Yankey doodle, and he will carry us to de Martinique, where we vel live upon l'amour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: And a little money, mon ami, ſo I'll go and ſecure the old gentleman's ſtrong box or coffre ſort, as you call it; but above all, remember to bind the Yankey to ſecrecy, for fear of a diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: No feré, no feré, de Yankey doodle love de l'argent too much for make de diſcover, I vil give he nof of dat, no feré.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Well, well, go and ſecure him directly.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Je vol, I fly, ma charmant, adeau mon coaeur. (Sings.) Adeau, ma princeſſa, il faut partir. (Going, returns.) Ecouté donc no forget de coffre fort, de ſtronga box.

div.stage: [During this laſt ſpeech they look tenderly at each other, at parting, dividing the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: Good People all ſhut all you year, open all you yi, harken to my tory, da hangman teef.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Take care muma Priſcilla, egad you mout make you fool: ſuppoſe you gim me ſaucy, I take my tick, I hit you be • m. (Sings.)

lg.l: As I was a goin a long, Priſcilla come for take me,
I take my tick 〈◊〉 brake he head, and that the way for whack he.
I never no de like man.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: You no hab ſhame, for uſe ſomebody, fo look'a my poor peak'ney, he yi tan like for you, he back tan like for you, you can have de heart, for leave poor ting ſo, O, O. (Cries.)

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: No vex yera. (Aſide.) I no can tan ſee yi run water ſo.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: Conſider he da you pick'ney.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Da true.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: You da he daddy.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: True ra muma.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: When you marry de lady, dem will bang poor little Quaka.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: No talk ſo, poor lille ſoul.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: Worka like a horſe; hungry da kill he.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Yam babrakoo.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: No fill he belly.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Poor he one.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: Up all night.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Driver da wrong he.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: If he peak obaſeer, da bang he. (Both ſhouting together) O Lord, oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: What is here fur do? You, Priſcilla, you no hab de impurence of de dibel, to make ſuch a noiſe in a my houſe?

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: I no hab right for come ſee my huſband?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Who da you huſband?

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: Banana da my huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Who tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: Da, me tell myſelf ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Who, you, you?

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: Me, me, me, me, Priſcilla.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: You mullatto Seaſar, go tell de obaſeer for come turn dis imperence huſſy out of doors.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: Lard a mighty in a tap, me poor one in a buckra country; you eber been hear de like of dat—me da imperence huſſy—eh—who da you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Me da lady.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: You da dible, look a like a lady; tigh, dirty no come dab me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Me hab plantation.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: You, ye lookee like a mumu; you mout like a bull-frog.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Me hab nega like a you.

sp.speaker: Priſcilla.
sp.p: You, lye, you ſeſy yi, you mumu noſe, you daddy mout chew tobacco, fire gun beem; me no care dat for you.

div.stage: Snaps her teeth with her fingers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Cato, Quaminu, ſomebody come and carry dis yere dibel to de juſtice, for tie up he mout.

div.stage: Enter Negroes, who take hold of Priſſey and carry her off.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Sorry, ſorry for me do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: How ſorry for you, you fool?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: No let dem bang poor Priſſey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: How come ſo?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Becauſe, mumma, I lob her too much.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: You hab de face for tell me ſo? you no hab no more amminition in you than one hog. Lookee dere (ſhews a letter) da from Mr. Fingercaſh; call de obarſeer, he will read him for you. Here he de come. (Enter Overſeer.) Bery well, read dat dere for you young maſſa.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Yes, da me, me da you maſſa—tye man!

body.p:
I have well weighed your propoſals, and have at length determined your ſon ſhall have my daughter. Altho' ſhe ſeems extremely averſe to the union, time may reconcile her to the huſband. Be that as it will, if you are willing to run the riſque, ſhe ſhall not diſpute my authority. The ſooner the ceremony is over the better, as delays are
dangerous with obſtinate children—If you have no objections, this evening would be moſt agreeable to your obedient ſervant,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Dere, dere for you! go in your chamber, make yourſelf mackey beau, for go marry wid de lady.

sp.speaker: Banana
sp.p: Lard, mumma, I no hab de heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: How come ſo?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: When de lady put hefyi upon me, I will ſhame ſo.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Keep heart, my ſhild, neber fear; come let a me ſee how you will berave yourſelf when you come before company.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: I will ax dem how ebrey body do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
Banana.
sp.p: Es, mumma, but what I mus ſay to de young lady?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: You muſt gib he ſweet mout, tell him you love he better dan all the world.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Better more dan Priſſey?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: You no can ſhut your mout about dat coloured dibel. Go put on you tings, and I will tell you how for make de girl fool as we go on the road.

Poor me one, my mumma tink ſhe hab ſabby in ſhe head. Egad, ſhe fool more dan poor me; ſhe want a me for marry de fine lady, to make my head grow big like a guaba buſh. Niber mind, I will marry de fine lady for pleaſe my mumma, and go lib wid Priſſey and poor little Quacka for pleaſe myſelf.

div.stage: Scene changes to Mr. Fingercaſh's Houſe. Enter Mr. and Miſs Fingercaſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Well, Miſs Pert, what are your reaſons why you will not marry this ignoramus, as you call him, who is as rich as a Jew?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: My deareſt father, can you aſk me that queſtion? Does not the difference of our education plead moſt powerfully againſt it, in breaking the laws of delicacy and ſociety, by joining two perſons whoſe ſouls are ſo very oppoſite in ſentiment?

sp.speaker: Mr Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Hark'ee, Miſs, none of your figurative capers with me; I have ſent for Mr. Banana, and you ſhall marry him this evening, I am reſolved upon it. Going.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: On my knees I beg you hear me: Can you reſolve to give up your child to a being that the moſt abandoned of our ſex would loath and ſpurn at?—The very thought ſtrikes me with madneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: By the Lord well acted! a chip of the old block, romance to the bottom, the mother from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, do not force your daughter to ſacrifice her duty to her love—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Eh, how, what's that! In the name of all that's obſtinate, what does the girl mean?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And make her fly for protection from your tyranny into the arms of the man ſhe adores.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo! excellentiſſimo! ten flights above any thing your mother ever ſoared to yet. But who is this mighty champion, this knight-errant, who will ſtand forth in your defence?

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: I am he, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: What, with a quiver of quills and a ſhield of parchment? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: No, Sir, with my life and fortune.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Pounce and ink-powder—Well ſaid Ledger—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: I have a fortune, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Yes, if you could but get any one to give you a fair title to it—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Do you think, Sir, I would tell you a lie?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: One? ay, a thouſand to get the handling of my ſtrong box, and leave to make an entry into the heart of that young lady.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: That he has already done, and no power on earth ſhall ever eraſe it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Zounds! was ever man ſo inſulted by a romantic girl and a beggarly adventurer, whom I took from ſtarving out of a priſon, and who now wants to rob me of my daughter, and I know not what beſides? —Get out of my houſe, Sir, and if you ever dare to come within theſe doors again, I'll have you committed to priſon.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Take care, Sir, how you threaten; recollect your villainous practices have put you in my power, not me in yours.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Egad, he has me there; I muſt act with caution in this affair, and get rid of him as quick as poſſible. (Aſide.) I have it—Look'ee, Sir, I have not ſo bad an opinion of you as to ſuppoſe you could be guilty of ingratitude, and I believe your happineſs muſt be concerned to force you to betray your benefactor; therefore, if you will promiſe not to take any advantage of me for this evening, I may take the affair into conſideration, provided you can bring any proofs of your having even the expectation of a fortune.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: I agree to your propoſals, and you may reſt ſatisfied I ſhall take no ſtep to yours or the young lady's injury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Very well, very well, that's a good lad, go to the counting-houſe and make out the Yankey's account. [Exit Ledger.] And you, Miſs, go to your mother's room, I'll follow you there. [Exit Louiſa.] So I have quieted their minds by a vain hope, and as ſoon as Banana arrives I'll have her ſecretly carried off in a carriage to Pierre Jean's, and married; and as for her gallant, I'll get him off the iſland coſt what it will.— Oh, apropos, here comes the very man I wanted. (Enter Amant and Captain.) Well friend N •• rard, how goes it?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Bad enough.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I am bewitched, I wiſh I never had left daddy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: What, has any of the Negroes been practiſing their obeo on you?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: No, it's neither obeo nor o, b, e, c, but the tarniſh roguiſh looks of that ſatin's imp, Miſs Bellmange.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: What has ſhe done to you?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Done, ecod I can't tell what ſhe has done to me, ſhe has made me feel all over.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Why, you are in love man.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: May be ſo. Now, can you tell me any cure for that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Marriage, to be ſure; did I not tell you you would carry off ſome of our Creole girls!

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Oh Lord, have I come all the way over ſeas to fall in love with a ſcreetch-owl?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: She's a fine girl, an't ſhe?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Ay, ſhe may be fine enough for theſe parts, but ſhe would not ſuit our markets; I would give all I am worth in the world, and mammy's hogs in the bargain, that I had never ſeen her face, for when I do go home to daddy's, ſhe'll haunt me like a ghoſt, I ſhall be ſo thinking about her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Ah, my good friend, if you would but do me a ſmall ſervice, I would put you in a way of curing your love, and making your fortune.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I vow now if you an't the beſt friend I ever had in my born days, I could find in my heart to fight through thick and thin to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Give me your hand, my honeſt fellow, why, I knew you were the lad for my purpoſe the moment I ſaw you. You know my clerk?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, what about him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: He has robb'd me.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I ſwear and ſwamp it, who would have thought he was ſuch a devil?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: 'Tis too true. Now, as the young fellow is of a good family, I would not wiſh him to come to public ſhame; if you will carry him home with you, you ſhall have my conſent to marry Miſs Bellange, and that will be the making of your fortune.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Eh, Captain, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Try your luck man, faint heart never won a fair lady.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Agreed; but ſuppoſe I don't get her conſent now, may I try it again next voyage?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you can't expect it this, for you muſt off directly; I will make out your account this inſtant, and give you the balance in caſh, my boy.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: What, hard caſh?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Hard as iron, my lad. It will be curſed hard if I don't bilk you out of it tho'. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I ſhall have the young lady when I get her conſent, for certain?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: O yes, undoubtedly. If your head don't ache till then, you'll have luck my lad. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Ecod then I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: You muſt gag him till you get him aboard, for he'll be declaring his innocence, and keep him cloſe under the hatches till you get clear of the land, he's a bloody minded fellow.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Don't you put yourſelf into any conſternations about it. I'll turn kidnapper for once, and ſell my ſoul to the old boy, but I take you both to witneſs 'tis for that ſnake of temptation call'd a Woman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'll give you a certificate, that you are a dam'd jack-aſs. (Aſide.) Gentlemen, I'll go and prepare your caſh for you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Well, my friend, what think you now?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: That fortune has ſmiled auſpicious on your ſchemes, and that you will be as ſucceſsful as any hero that every trod the region of romance; and your meeting with your friend Ledger, who you ſuppoſed died in priſon, is as romantic an incident as ever turned up to any Quixote of them all.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p:
Yes, faith, but the Frenchman's' intrigue crowns all; that ſecret will command what terms I pleaſe for myſelf, and Ledger too I hope. He has wrote to the Governor on the tyranny of the old gentleman's forcing his daughter to a prepoſterous match with Banana,
ſo we muſt wait his arrival before we open our plot. You have got poſſeſſion of the ſtrong box, the coffre fort?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Safe.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Then allons vive l'amour. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Fingercaſh's Houſe continued. Mrs. Fingercaſh and Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Well, child, my heart is ſoftened by your tears and entreaties, and you may depend on my aſſiſtance, if you can deviſe any ſcheme to counteract your brute of a father; and to prevent any ſuſpicion, you muſt ſeem to comply with his wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Well, wife, does Miſs begin to liſten to reaſon?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, my elocution has at length ſubdued her obſtinacy, and ſhe is convinced of her error?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Then, if that is the caſe, I freely forgive her, and am proud to find ſhe is diſpoſed to receive her intended huſband with propriety.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Miſſes Banana da come wid he ſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Shew them in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: We are all happy to ſee you on occaſion that will put your ſon in poſſeſſion of as fine a girl as any in the country, (aſide,) and me of his money.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: You ſavant, Sir, you ſavant, Ladies, I am as proud as you can be, an do my ſon no ſchola, he hab a heart.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Big like a pumkin, mumma.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Shut you mout.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Yes, no bex yere.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: What make you tan ſo?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Tie, mumma, you no ſee me tan on my foot; how I muſt tan?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Where all dem fine tings I been learn you for ſay?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Tie, dem gone, dem gone out o' my head, an no ſabby catch 'em.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Son, Banana, that is to be, your moſt obedient, you are grown vaſtly corpulent ſince I had laſt the pleaſure of ſeeing you.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Yes, a' daddy, me da corporal in de militia, me da go ſajant nex a year.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: You fool like a trokey, you no hab no mo gramification in you dan if you neber been larn you letter. Why you no peak to de lady, man?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Marra ma'am. (Goes ſneekingly up to her, then retires.) Lud, mamma, I no ſabby do um.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Mrs. Banana, your ſon is rather modeſt; he is baſhful before company; ſuppoſe we leave the young folks together, I have ſomething to communicate to you in private?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Wid all my heart, Sir.

div.stage: Exit Mr. and Mrs. Fingercaſh, and Mrs. Banana.
(As Mrs. Banana is going off, Banana catches her by the ſleeve; ſhe puſhes him back.)

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: No leab a poo me, ſhame da kill me, Lard wha me da go do, my yi turn, my heart go tumpity tump, my knee go bumpity bumity bump.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Poor wretch, he ſeems quite confounded with the inequality of his ſituation.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: (Timidly approaching Louiſa.) Suppoſe you no bex, I will tell you one tory; I lobe a you, I lobe a you, like peppa pot my heart da burn, a burn a like a fire coal, put you yi ſweet upon me, ſorry fo' me, ſorry fo' me, ſorry fo' me do, or I da go dead like a one pig.

div.stage: Enter Ledger from a cloſet, with a piſtol.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Say that again, you ſcoundrel, and I'll ſend this bullet through your head.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: O Lord, Oh!— (Falls down on his face.)

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Offer to ſquall and I'll— (Points the piſtol at him, Banana looking up with terror.)

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Lod, I dead a ready.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: You wretch, how cou'd you dare—

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Ax a pardon, good man, da no been me.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Who then?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Da been, da been, da —

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Speak cut, you raſcal.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Lod, me no ſabby peak.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Da ſometing you hab dere look angry ſo.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: What, this?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Yes, ſhut up he mout, no let he talk, and I will tell you one tory.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: (Puts up the piſtol.) Now go on.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: My mumma want a fo' ride grande, gallop away prookety, prookety, prook; me know me da foole, and me want fo' walk tofly, tofly; you ſabby, tofly catch quickly; me mumma want me for marry wid de fine lady, I want fo' go lib wid my own lobe Priſſey.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: What, you have got a miſtreſs then?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Yes, an pickney too. You no know little Quacka?

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: And don't you love your Priſſey?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Yes, I lobe he like a hell, and ſhe lobe me like a dibel.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Well, if ever you wiſh to ſee Priſſey's face again, go into that chamber, put on a ſuit of clothes you'll find there, and don't dare to move or ſpeak till I bring you out; then you ſhall be lawfully married to her.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Bleſs a you heart, good ſoul, I will do ebery ting you bid a me. (Going to the cloſet returns.) Lod, I want fo' beg you one ſometing.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Fo' •• ang my mumma, curſe he old heart.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Remember, don't ſtir, or I'll— (Pulls out the piſtol.)

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: O Lod! O Lod! Exits terrified.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Now, my Louiſa, every thing goes on to our wiſh—give this note to your maid to give your father; that will prevent his going with you to Pere Jean's. I'll go maſk my face and put on Banana's clothes; the coachman is in my intereſt, and is willing to be deceived. Exit Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Well, have you ſucceeded with Banana?

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: To a miracle; it was the wiſh of the poor wretch to get an opportunity of being off.—The Governor will be here about the hour the prieſt has made Louiſa mine—Are your ſailors in readineſs?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes; but I don't fully underſtand how you intend to conduct this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: 'Tis thus; I overheard a converſation between Louiſa and her mother, who has yielded to her entreaties, and promiſes her aſſiſtance. Louiſa's maid, under pretence of betraying me, will give the old gentleman a note, making an appointment to meet his daughter at the place and hour the Frenchman has fixed for eloping with Mrs. Fingercaſh. Now, you muſt be ready with your ſailors to carry off the Frenchman, whom Fingercaſh will ſuppoſe to be me, as he is to be maſk'd, you know.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Ay, now I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh▪
sp.p: (from within.) Louiſa, Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Zounds! here is the old fellow; I muſt to my hiding-place. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Have you ſeen Louiſa this way?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: No; I have been looking for her to get her to ſpeak a good word for me when I am gone.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: I wiſh you was ſafe gone, and that villain Ledger along with you. Would you believe it, not content with robbing me, he keeps lurking about with an intention to run away with my daughter; her maid has betrayed them, and gave me this note, appointing a rendezvous. Now, my dear fellow, to prove yourſelf worthy of my friendſhip and Miſs Bellange's love, be you and your ſailors ready to go along with me, and we'll there gag him and carry him on board.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Oh, never fear me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Boy, [enter ſeavant] tell your miſtreſs to come here—Are your hands ſtout fellows? To Amant.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: They are not over and above ſtout, but I believe they are fellows. Looks at his hands.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Stupid aſs! (aſide) your men I mean?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, fine chowder-fed boys.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: What do you want, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh,
sp.p: (going to ſhew the letter.) No, I'll not truſt her 'till 'tis all over.—My dear, I have a preſſing reaſon why I ſhould wiſh this buſineſs of our daughter's was finiſhed, and muſt requeſt you to go in my place to Pere Jean's. There is no time to be loſt, ſo you muſt about it this inſtant, and return immediately after the ceremony, for then my fears will have an end.—Come along with me, honeſt Jonathan, and I'll ſettle with you.

Surely he does not ſuſpect me—oh no—my daughter ſaid ſhe would ſend him on a wrong ſcent till her affair is over, and this is the moſt charming opportunity for me to make off with my ſpark. I'll ſee if Ledger is ready. Hiſt, hiſt. [Goes to the door, it opens.] Oh, you are ready, I ſee; my daughter and I will call on you in an inſtant. Remember, you muſt turn me out of the coach as ſoon as we loſe ſight of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Is the old gentleman ſecured?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: All ready, and now for a trip to the land of love. Exit.

div.stage: Scene a Jeſſamine Bower. Enter Frenchman maſked.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: This is the arbour of jaſſamine, I vill go ſecure my prize.

div.stage: [He enters, the door flies back, followed by Fingercaſh, Amant, and ſailors.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Seize him! ſeize him! at him, my boys, at him!

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Oh des voleurs! des voleurs! Murder! murder!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Yes, yes, theſe are thieves, and you are one of them. You was punctual to the hour, and you did not find me behind hand.

sp.speaker: Frenchman,
sp.p: (the ſailors tying him.) Ecoute moi?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Changing your language won't do; we are prepared for you, altho' the lady was'n't.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Je ſuis ennocent je vous.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: There, did I not tell you he would plead innocent: gag him, gag him.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Waw, waw, waw, waw, de Yankey doodle. (They endeavour to ſtop his mouth, he continues the noiſe.) Waw, waw, waw.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: He ſings Yankey doodle to a new tune, and waw, waw, waw, make a moſt excellent chorus.

div.stage: (The ſailors take him on their ſhoulders.)

sp.speaker: Sailors.
sp.p: Well, Sir, we are all ready for ſailing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Stop, I muſt give your paſſenger his clearance. (The old man flogs him on the back with his cane; the ſailors marching round the ſtage; old man ſinging Yankey doodle, waw, waw, Yankey doodle dandy; and at the laſt blow) that's the dandy!

div.stage: [The time he is beating the Frenchman Mrs. Fingercaſh▪ enters, and goes off again unperceived.]
Scene changes to a Chamber in Mr. Fingercaſh's houſe. Miſs Bellange and Governor ſeated.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: I am very glad, Madam, you have had recourſe to theſe artifices, for had I been obliged to interpoſe with my authority, it might have been attended with diſagreeable conſequences to this cruel father.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bellange.
sp.p: Still, Sir, I muſt requeſt you to ſpeak in the ſame abſolute ſtile to Mr. Fingercaſh you have done to Acid, for he is the moſt artful of men.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: I conceive your meaning, and will attend to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Your Excellency's moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: Soldat. (Enter two ſoldiers and take hold of Fingercaſh.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Gentlemen, what is the meaning of of all this? (To the Governor.) I am ſorry, Sir, I am not at liberty to give you my beſt welcome in this houſe, as theſe gentlemen ſeem to be maſters of the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: This pleaſantry will not ſoften my reſentment; I am come here to ſee juſtice done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Sir, the bird is flown, your juſtice cannot extend to the ſtretching Mr. Ledger's neck this time.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: What, Sir, do you take me for a hangman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: No, Sir, but he is the only offender about my houſe.

div.stage: Enter Amant, Mrs. Fingercaſh, and Mrs. Banana. Amant ſtares, and bows to the Governor, then paſſes over to Fingercaſh.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Lord, what's the matter friend? ſure you are not going to ſing to the tune of Yankey doodle, waw, waw, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Peace, man; ſwear to whatever I ſay, and you ſhall have Miſs Bellange, and her fortune into the bargain, whether ſhe will or not.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: You may depend upon me, Sir; I'll ſtand by you, till you get your deſerts, you ſcoundrel. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: You have heard, Sir, of the robbery he has committed?

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: No, Sir, I have heard of no robbery.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Sir, he has almoſt ruin'd me.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: I'll ſwear right down point blank he has.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Beſides, he wanted to carry off my daughter, and tri'd all he could to get the poor innocent Yankey to join him in the plot.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, I'll be drot if he did'n't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: A wicked black plot, Sir, as ever you heard of.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, a tarnaſhon black plot the whole of it, and here comes a fellow with a black patch on his face to prove it.

div.stage: Enter Ledger, (diſguiſed as Banana,) and Louiſa. They kneel.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Your bleſſing, daddy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: How, ſure this an't Banana?

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: No, Sir, but your own Ledger, neatly bound by father Jean, and elegantly gilded by this lady's hand.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: A curs'd black plot indeed!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: What, are you concern'd in it too?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Me, Sir; if I had any hand in patching that black face, I wiſh the devil may take me. Oh Lord, there he is.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Revenche, revenche, de Yankey doodle, et de goudron de feder, de feder and goudron. (The Frenchman runs after Amant, who at length hides behind the Governor.)

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Yes, you are very well feathered, and I have made a very good run to keep clear of old nick. Do Governor, keep him off.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Mon General.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: Ecod, I never knew the old boy had got a commander before.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: Ah, you are there, Mr. Deſerter; vous ſerrai pendu mon ami.

div.stage: Soldiers go from Fingercaſh to the Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: What, are you going to ſing the ſecond part of Yankey doodle, waw, waw?

div.stage: Puts his hand to his neck.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: I am loſt in amazement. Wife, in the profundity of your wiſdom can you find any mode to expound this? What, your figurative ſtore exhauſted!

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it has taken flight, and you may think yourſelf extremely happy it has not carried your ſolid ſtuff along with it. What ſay you, Monſieur? the coffre fort, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Eh, what's that about the ſtrong box? Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: [Kneels.] I ax pardon, my aminition been make me fool, I no been know myſelf, no puniſh me for my prerumption, I puniſh enough already, I looſe my poor pickney; wha me da go do for my poor pickney, oh?

div.stage: [Ledger opens the door, Banana runs to his mother, kiſſes her.]

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Here me mumma.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Banana.
sp.p: Lard, my pickney.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Tye mumma.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: I am robb'd, I am robb'd! Governer, I requeſt juſtice; order your ſoldiers to ſecure every body in the houſe, that my money may be reſtored.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: My intention in coming here was to ſee juſtice done every one.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Lard, mumma, take care, maſſa Ledger been promiſe to bang you, he will pay you well.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: No, Banana, your goodneſs—

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Yes, me da good boy.

sp.speaker: Ledger.
sp.p: Protects yourſelf and mother.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Tank you. (To his mother) Keep heart, old ſoul.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: Now, gentlemen, Banana's buſineſs being over —

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: Me da go marry Priſſey.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: Peace, Sir.

sp.speaker: Banana.
sp.p: I done, maſſa, no bex yere.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: Advance your different claims, and let me know the nature of them.

sp.speaker: Amant,
sp.p: (ſpeaks in his own tone.) I believe, Sir, mine ſtands firſt upon the liſt. Fingercaſh ſtarts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Hey day! in the name of wonder, who are you, pray?

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: My name is Amant, a favoured admirer of this lady's, whoſe fortune I now demand; my right of claim to it being your and her conſent to our union.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Well, this makes good the old ſaying, that a true bred Yankey is a match for the devil:—But you'll find yourſelf miſtaken in her fortune—I have large demands againſt the eſtate.

sp.speaker: Amant.
sp.p: How juſtly founded my friend Ledger can explain—You ſee I'm a match for you every way— Remember you ſaid I was the boy for your purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: You find, Sir, from your ungovernable deſire of riches, you not only put people upon their guard againſt you, but oblige them to deſcend to the loweſt arts, to defeat you in your villainy. To ſuch a degrading ſtate of infamy did you lower yourſelf, that you made even your wife and child abhor you as a monſter that knew no diſtinction of either appetite or ſentiment: that abhorrence gave riſe to inconſtancy in the one, and diſobedience in the other. The only atonement you can now make for your paſt errors, is to return to the paths of honour and honeſty, and by your endeavours to make your family happy, be reinſtated in their loves.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fingercaſh.
sp.p: Your words are backed with truth and ſound reaſon, and I'm become their convert. I humbly beg pardon for the trouble I have given you: But if you and this good company will bury in oblivion my paſt errors, and thoſe of the YORKER'S STRATAGEM, I ſhall for the future only exiſt in meriting your—no— (to the audience) their approbation.
